questions.text: A dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure undergoes cystoscopy. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoscopy with removal of tumor

 

  • This is the diagnostic and therapeutic first-line step.
  • Tissue obtained is sent for histopathology to confirm grade/stage.

 

We’re looking at a cystoscopic image that shows a papillary, exophytic, frond-like growth inside the bladder.

 

The clinical context:

 

  • Patient = dye factory worker → occupational exposure to aromatic amines (e.g., benzidine, β-naphthylamine) → strong risk factor for urothelial carcinoma of the bladder.
  • Lesion = looks like a papillary bladder tumor.
  • First-line management = transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) (here described as “cystoscopy with removal of tumor”).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV BCG: Used in non–muscle invasive bladder cancer after TURBT (as adjuvant). Not the primary step.

 

Option C. TURP (Transurethral resection of prostate): Procedure for benign prostatic hyperplasia, not bladder tumor.

 

Option D. Radical cystectomy: Indicated for muscle-invasive bladder cancer or recurrent high-grade lesions, not the initial step.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the office due to fever, dysuria, and abdominal pain. The patient has had several urinary tract infections since her teens but has no other medical concerns. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic discomfort. Urinalysis demonstrates pyuria and many bacteria. CT scan of the abdomen is shown in the image below:

 

 

Which of the following structures has most likely limited the proper ascent of the anomalous organ seen on CT scan?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Inferior mesenteric artery

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use ionizing radiation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) FAST

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image.
questions.solution: Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in his left shoulder. He is physically active and plays baseball twice a week. The pain is reproduced when the shoulder is externally rotated against resistance. Injury of which of the following tendons is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Infraspinatus

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The patient has a right-sided varicocele (soft strands above testis, increases with Valsalva, non-transilluminating).
  • Sudden-onset or adult varicocele on the right side in a patient >40 years suggests secondary varicocele due to obstruction of venous drainage, commonly from retroperitoneal mass compressing the IVC (renal cell carcinoma, retroperitoneal tumor).
  • Right testicular vein drains directly into the IVC, whereas the left drains into the left renal vein. Hence IVC obstruction affects the right side predominantly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Right internal iliac vein: Drains the pelvis; unlikely to cause isolated right-sided varicocele.

 

Option B. Right inferior rectal vein: Drains anorectal region; obstruction would cause hemorrhoids, not varicocele.

 

Option C. Right renal vein: Left-sided varicoceles are more commonly associated with left renal vein compression (Nutcracker syndrome), not right-sided.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the calf muscles after walking for a certain distance. The pain is relieved by rest and reoccurs upon resuming walking. Based on Boyd’s classification, what is the most likely grade?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade III

 

Boyd’s classification is used to grade peripheral arterial disease (PAD) based on clinical symptoms:

 

 

The patient experiences calf pain after walking a certain distance, relieved by rest, fitting Grade III (moderate claudication).

questions.text: Following head trauma, patient opens eyes to pain, localize pain on right and withdraws on left side, and speaks incoherent words. His GCS is:
questions.solution: Ans. C) 10

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic tingling and numbness in his right hand for the past 3 weeks. He says that he cannot hold a pen very well and that this is affecting his handwriting. Sensation to light touch is decreased over the right little finger and the medial palmar surface of the right hand. Radiologic evaluation in this patient is most likely to show a fracture in which of the following bones?
questions.solution: Ans. D) G

questions.text: A patient presented with dysphagia to both solid and liquids. Manometry revealed IRP > 15 and >20% premature spastic contractions but no peristalsis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Achalasia type 3

questions.text:
Identify the wrong component:

 

1) Thoracoscore – Priority of surgery

2) ASESPIS score-Induration

3) Kings college criteria-Jaundice <7 days before development of encephalopathy

4) Van Nuys grading-Invasion
questions.solution: Ans. D) 2, 3

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Alkaptonuria

choices.text: Abdominal CT imaging is required
He is at risk of poisoning

questions.text: A person at the airport with symptoms showing agitations showed following x- ray findings. He was carrying enema apparatus and laxatives. Which of the following is a wrong statement?
questions.solution: Ans. B) He is malingering

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the doctor because of gradually progressive weakness in her right hand over the past few weeks. She goes to the gym to lift weights 5 times a week. With the dorsum of the right hand on a flat surface, the patient is unable to move her thumb to touch a pen held 2 cm above the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. An MRI of the right arm shows compression of a nerve that passes through the pronator teres muscle. Based on the examination findings, loss of innervation of which of the following muscles is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was thrown from his motor-cycle and brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services. The paramedics report his initial blood pressure was 83/52 mmHg, pulse was 128/min, and respiratory rate was 33/min. He was given 2 L of lactated Ringer’s solution en route. On arrival to the trauma bay his blood pressure is 108/76 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respiratory rate is 28/min. On examination pelvic compression elicits severe pain, and blood is noted at the urethral meatus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating the blood at the urethral meatus?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Retrograde urethrogram

questions.text: An adolescent fell on an outstretched hand. For management, the doctor ties a cast as shown in the given image. Which fracture did the patient suffer from?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Scaphoid fracture

questions.text: Following a major road accident, a 25-year-old male is stabilized in casualty. He is noticed to have abdominal bruising, for which a CECT abdomen is done. A zone 1 retroperitoneal hematoma is found. In suspected abdominal aortic injury, exposure is achieved via which manoeuvre?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Mattox

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a mobile, rubbery mass in her left breast. A histological image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis for the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma

 

The histology image shows well-circumscribed, proliferative stromal and glandular tissue with slit-like spaces, fitting with the classic features of fibroadenoma. Clinically, the description of a mobile, rubbery breast mass in a young female further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: Shows infiltrating malignant epithelial cells with desmoplastic stroma, not the well-organized pattern seen here.

 

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Displays leaf-like (phyllode) architecture with increased stromal cellularity and atypia, often less circumscribed than fibroadenoma.

 

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma in-situ: Characterized by small, discohesive cells filling and expanding lobules, lacking the orderly stroma and glandular proliferation

questions.text: Seven hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. Neurologic examination shows left leg strength 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Femoral nerve injury

questions.text: A 50 year old patient with a history of achalasia, had undergone a POEM, following which he developed left sided chest pain. HRCT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Esophageal rupture

choices.text: Looks like a normal foot
Squatting is not possible
There is no restriction of movement

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding the given image:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Squatting is not possible

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with pain on movement. X-ray of knee joint shows lytic lesion on the upper end of fibula as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Osteoclastoma

questions.text: All of the following are correctly paired with HU on CT except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat: 0-20

 

  • Fat typically has a HU range of approximately -100 to -50, which means it appears less dense than water (0 HU) on CT scans. The value 0-20 HU does not correspond to fat but rather to other soft tissues or fluids.
  • Contrast material generally ranges from 100-300 HU depending on concentration, so 130 HU is a reasonable value for contrast-enhanced areas.
  • Acute hemorrhage usually has a HU range around 60-70, reflecting the density of fresh blood on CT.
  • Calcification appears hyperdense on CT, with very high HU values often between 800-1000 or higher, representing dense calcium deposits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contrast: 130: This is a typical attenuation value for iodinated contrast in vessels or organs on CT scan and falls within expected ranges.

 

Option C. Acute hemorrhage: 60-70: Fresh blood appears hyperdense on CT, commonly with HU values in this range.

 

Option D. Calcification: 800-1000: Dense calcium deposits have very high attenuation, consistent with this HU range on CT.

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. On examination, his right arm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radial head subluxation

 

This presentation is classic for radial head subluxation (nursemaid’s elbow):

 

  • Age group: Most common in children 1–4 years.
  • Mechanism: Sudden longitudinal traction on the arm (e.g., lifting, pulling, swinging by the hands).
  • Clinical finding: Child holds the arm in slight flexion and pronation, refuses to use it, and is very irritable.
  • X-ray: Usually normal (clinical diagnosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal ulnar fracture: Would present with swelling, deformity, and tenderness; not just refusal to move.

 

 

Option B. Anterior shoulder dislocation: Rare in toddlers; arm would be abducted and externally rotated, not flexed/pronated.

 

 

Option C. Supracondylar fracture of the humerus: Common after fall on outstretched hand; presents with swelling, pain, and risk of neurovascular compromise.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus with low grade dysplasia is 0.7% per year.
  2. The iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured during Rutherford-Morrison incision
  3. Muscularis propria breached in Carcinoma rectum is Duke Stage A.
  4. Replaced right hepatic artery arising from superior mesenteric artery is the most common vascular anomaly of the liver.
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

questions.text:
Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years:

 

A. Capsulotomy

B. Femoral osteotomy

C. Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament

D. Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.solution: Ans. C) A→C→B→D

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of damage control surgery:

 

  1. Hemorrhage control
  2. Definitive repair
  3. Abdomen closure
  4. Resuscitation in ICU
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1,4,2,3

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents to emergency department with pain in right hip and is unable to walk. She gives a history of fall in bathroom. On examination, you observe that there is shortening of left lower limb and is externally rotated. There is no history of arthritis. X-ray of hip is given below. What will be the management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Hemiarthroplasty

Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings
Malpositioning of the genital tubercle

questions.text: A male newborn is born at 37 weeks' gestation after spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother had no prenatal care. Physical examination shows a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis, 4 mm proximal to the glans. The physical appearance is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Malpositioning of the genital tubercle

questions.text: Identify the anti-reflux procedure in the image:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Floppy Nissen fundoplication

questions.text: A patient underwent endoscopy. During the procedure perforation occurred at 25 cm from the incisors. Which structure is likely to be damaged?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Arch of aorta

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain that began approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that radiates to his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath and nausea. On physical exam, his blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. The ECG shows ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels are elevated. What test can detect areas of reversible myocardial ischemia in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Thallium scan

choices.text: Massive pleural effusion
Patient who has undergone pneumonectomy
Complete main bronchial obstruction

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dyspnea and left-sided chest pain. On physical examination, you note decreased breath sounds on the left side. Chest radiography is performed. Which of the following is least likely to cause an opaque left hemithorax on the radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Massive Pneumothorax

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with gastroesophageal reflux disease and osteoarthritis is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe, stabbing epigastric pain. For the last 6 months, he has had progressively worsening right knee pain, for which he takes ibuprofen several times a day. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia without ST-segment elevations or depressions. This patient is most likely to have referred pain in which of the following locations?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Left shoulder

choices.text: Cetrimide, Hypertonic saline may be used for PAIR

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient underwent a routine USG following which this finding was noted. What is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) PAIR is the treatment of choice in cysto-biliary communication.

questions.text: Identify the nerve supply of the marked muscle:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Median Nerve

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with continuous dribbling of saliva and choking while feeding. CXR is shown here. Identify the type of TEF:

questions.solution: Ans. C) Susceptibility weighted image

Lack of testicular fixation

questions.text: A 4-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his father because of swelling of his left hemiscrotum. Physical examination shows a nontender left scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass increases in size when the boy cries but is easily reducible. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Patent processus vaginalis

USG is the best investigation to diagnose
Peristalsis from left to right side of abdomen may be seen on feeding

questions.text:
A male child presented with vomiting at 3 weeks of age. An X ray was taken that shows the following:

 

 

What is false regarding the above condition?

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is done for the treatment of Pilonidal sinus as shown?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Transposition flap

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was brought to the trauma centre following a road traffic accident. He was walking on the street when a car hit him from the side and severely injured his left knee. An X-ray of the knee joint showing distal femur and proximal tibia-fibula was done. Identify the given fracture:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Bumper fracture

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability:

 

I. Ilizarov

II. Uniplanar frame with one rod

III. Biplanar frame

IV. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution: Ans. A) II, IV, III, I

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of pain in his right leg. His mother has been giving him ketorolac at night to improve his sleep, but the pain has not improved. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the right mid-femur. An x-ray of the right lower extremity is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ewing sarcoma

questions.text: All of these are components of Barcelona Clinic for Liver Cancer (BCLC) staging except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) AFP

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray?
questions.solution: Ans. A) ERCP and Bile duct

questions.text: According to the Strasberg’s classification of bile leaks, leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct comes under?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Type C

questions.text: Which of the following is not a utility of ultrasound imaging?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Treatment of coronary artery disease

Calcium normal, Phosphate normal, ALP normal, PTH normal
Calcium normal, Phosphate normal, ALP increased, PTH normal
Calcium normal, Phosphate increased, ALP increased, PTH increased

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to his physician's office for evaluation of a 9-month history of pain in the midline of his lower back. X-ray is shown below. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following sets of laboratory findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Calcium normal, Phosphate normal, ALP increased, PTH normal

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Billroth II reconstruction

 

The image shows a surgical procedure in which the distal stomach is resected and the gastric remnant is anastomosed to the side of the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum, which is characteristic of Billroth II (gastrojejunostomy) reconstruction.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Billroth I reconstruction: Involves gastroduodenostomy, connecting the stomach to the duodenum.


Option C. Braun anastomosis: An additional side-to-side jejunojejunostomy, not visualized here.

 

 

Option D. Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy: Features a Y-shaped configuration, with separation of the alimentary and biliopancreatic limbs, different from the simple gastrojejunostomy shown.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines?
questions.solution: Ans. C) C4a

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painless testicular mass that he first noticed while showering. Physical examination of the right testicle shows a firm, fixed, nontender 2-cm nodule. Ultrasound shows a well-defined, homogenous, hypoechoic 2.3 cm lesion in the right testicle. Laboratory studies show increased serum concentrations of hCG and placental alkaline phosphatase, and a serum alpha-fetoprotein concentration that is within the reference range. Right radical inguinal orchiectomy is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the removed testis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Seminoma

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD for evaluation of back pain. The pain has been constant for the last 2 weeks and keeps the patient from playing with his friends. He wakes up several times nightly to void and has had episodes of incontinence as the leg pain prevents him from walking to the bathroom. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe knee pain and swelling that began 30 minutes earlier while she was at soccer practice. She was running down the field, suddenly "cut inwards", and heard a loud pop when she first felt the pain. She is unable to bear weight on the right knee. Examination shows marked edema and tenderness to palpation of the anterior right knee. When the knee is flexed and anterior traction is provided to the foreleg, anterior translation of the foreleg is observed. An illustration of a normal right knee in anterior view is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is injury to which of the following labelled structures?
questions.solution: Ans. A) A

questions.text: In extended left hemi-hepatectomy, the liver segments resected are:
questions.solution: Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 8

choices.text: Right superior gluteal nerve palsy
Left superior gluteal nerve palsy
Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy
Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents to her oncologist with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started a few weeks 2 ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Lymphedema

questions.text: Identify the radiological procedure shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Enteroclysis

questions.text: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of pain in his left foot that increases with physical activity and improves with rest. He is a military recruit who started his basic combat training 6 weeks ago. Before he began military training, he did not exercise regularly. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); his BMI is 19 kg/m. Physical examination shows mild swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation over the forefoot. An x-ray of the left foot is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Stress fracture

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with bleeding during defecation and straining. Examination reveals pile mass which appears on straining, at 7 and 11 O'clock, which reduces spontaneously.  Preferred treatment:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barron’s Banding

 

Barron’s band ligation is the preferred and effective treatment for internal hemorrhoids that prolapse during straining but reduce spontaneously, typically grades II and III. It is a minimally invasive outpatient procedure with a high success rate and quick recovery.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: Usually reserved for higher-grade hemorrhoids with significant prolapse; more invasive and costly.
 

Option C. Milligan Morgan procedure: An open hemorrhoidectomy, used for large, symptomatic, or thrombosed hemorrhoids, not usually first-line for reducible piles. Image shown below demonstrates the procedure.
 

Option D. Sitz bath: A conservative measure to relieve symptoms but does not treat prolapsed hemorrhoids effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barron’s banding treats the underlying prolapse and bleeding effectively with minimal discomfort and downtime

choices.text: Sympathetic Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Sympathetic retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step
Bilateral orchidectomy must be done
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Right middle lobe consolidation

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of right elbow swelling and pain 30 minutes after falling onto her outstretched right arm. She has been unable to move her right elbow since the fall. Physical examination shows bruising, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with anterior displacement of the proximal fragment. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Absent distal radial pulse

choices.text: Milan criteria is applicable for single tumor up to 5 cm or three tumors each less than 3 cm
A FLR (future liver remnant) of at least 40% normal liver is a pre-requisite for resection
Colorectal metastasis to liver can be excised

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about management of hepatoma?
questions.solution: Ans. B) A FLR (future liver remnant) of at least 40% normal liver is a pre-requisite for resection

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

choices.text: Appendectomy 6 months ago
Fatty food intolerance
High alcohol consumption
Occasional black or tarry stool

questions.text: 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department with persistent vomiting and abdominal pain for the last 24 hours. The pain is crampy, difuse, and getting worse. He had a normal bowel movement 3 days ago and has no diarrhea. His abdomen is distended with hyperactive bowel sounds. Percussion reveals tympany, and the patient is diffusely tender to palpation. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following historical findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Appendectomy 6 months ago

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of transient ischemic attacks and several episodes of weakness is referred for diagnostic evaluation. On physical examination, there is a noticeable murmur around the child's temple. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is performed, revealing the characteristic imaging shown. The following appearance of DSA is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moya-Moya disease

 

The angiographic image demonstrates a classic “puff of smoke” appearance, which is characteristic of Moya-Moya disease. This disease involves progressive stenosis of the internal carotid arteries and compensatory development of a fine network of collateral vessels, leading to the described smoky vascular pattern on DSA.

 

Moya-Moya typically presents in children with recurrent transient ischemic attacks and focal neurological deficits. The presence of a bruit (vascular murmur) over the temple further supports the diagnosis due to increased collateral flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ICA aneurysm: Would show a localized outpouching or ballooning of the vessel on angiography, not a diffuse network of vessels.

 

 

Option C. Cerebral infarction: Usually results in hypoperfusion zones or absence of flow.

 

Option D. Carotid artery thrombosis: Would show abrupt cutoff or absence of flow in the involved vessel, without the collateral vascularization seen here.

choices.text: Duodenal ulcer rupture

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. Initially, the vomitus was food that he had recently eaten, but it is now bilious. He has had similar complaints several times in the past 6 years. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks 3 pegs of whiskey daily. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 48 kg (105 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an epigastric mass.The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely
questions.solution: Ans. C) Pancreatic pseudocyst

choices.text: Left gastric vein and azygos vein
Paraumbilical vein and inferior epigastric vein
Portal vein and inferior vena cava
Splenic vein and left renal vein

questions.text: A 57-year-old white man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of sudden-onset, bright red emesis. His blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg and heart rate is 124/min. Physical examination is notable for jaundice and an enlarged abdomen that is dull to percussion and positive for a fluid wave. Which of the following vessel anastomoses is responsible for the patient’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left gastric vein and azygos vein

 

  • The patient has hematemesis in the setting of portal hypertension (jaundice, ascites).
  • Esophageal varices are the most common cause of upper GI bleeding in cirrhosis.
  • Esophageal varices arise from portosystemic anastomosis between the left gastric vein (portal system) and azygos vein (systemic circulation).
  • Rupture leads to massive, bright red hematemesis and hypovolemic shock.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Paraumbilical vein and inferior epigastric vein: Form caput medusae; superficial abdominal varices, rarely bleed massively.

 

Option C. Portal vein and inferior vena cava: There is no direct anastomosis causing variceal bleeding; portal hypertension leads to collateral formation instead.

 

Option D. Splenic vein and left renal vein: Forms gastric or short gastric varices; less common and usually in splenic vein thrombosis, not general cirrhosis.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

 

During an extended right colectomy for proximal transverse colon carcinoma, the arterial supply from the ileocolic artery, right colic artery, and the main trunk of the middle colic artery must be ligated and resected. This ensures complete lymphovascular clearance to prevent the spread of cancer.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic: Not sufficient, as only the branch is resected, missing the main trunk.
 

Option B. Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic: Includes left colic, which is not part of the right-sided resection territory.
 

Option D. Middle colic only: Does not address the ileocolic and right colic arteries supplying the right colon and proximal transverse colon.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness > 3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: What is the management of choice for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Coiling

choices.text: Superior vesical artery
External anal sphincter

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a wellness visit. Physical examination shows an enlarged and nodular prostate. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of prostate-specific antigen. A prostate biopsy confirms the diagnosis of prostate cancer, and a radical prostatectomy is planned. This patient should be counselled on the increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cavernous nerve

choices.text: Rouviere’s sulcus to segment 5 of liver
Rouviere’s sulcus to segment 4 of liver

questions.text: While performing a cholecystectomy, surgeons ensure that dissection is performed above this particular line, since the cystic artery and cystic duct lie antero-superior to this line and the CBD lies below this line. The line mentioned in this question connects which 2 parts?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Rouviere’s sulcus to segment 4 of liver

choices.text: Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT
Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT
IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, intubation, CECT
IV cannulation, intubation, CECT, cervical spine stabilization

questions.text: In a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA, what is the correct sequence of management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath following a motor vehicle accident. Bedside ultrasonography is performed, and the image shown is obtained using M-mode. Which of the following signs is most likely being depicted in this ultrasound image?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Seashore sign

choices.text: Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle
Osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint
Avascular necrosis of the lunate bone
Hypesthesia of the hypothenar eminence

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of right wrist pain after a fall from a ladder. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength and tenderness between the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. X-ray of the right wrist shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint

questions.text:
A 43-year-old multiparous woman with no other medical history presents to her physician because of crampy abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice. Laboratory studies show:

 

Total bilirubin: 4.8 mg/dL

 

Direct bilirubin: 4.2 mg/dL

 

Amylase: 50 U/L
 

Lipase: 70 U/L

 

Aspartate aminotransferase: 75 U/L

 

Alanine aminotransferase: 70 U/L

 

The patient subsequently is sent for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography; results are shown in the image. What is the most likely cause of the obstruction seen in the image?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Choledocholithiasis

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient present with 4 cm diameter diagnosed breast cancer lesion with ipsilateral axillary and contralateral supraclavicular lymphadenopathy as shown below. As per AJCC system, patient belongs to which stage of breast cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. B) T4b N1 M1

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

Reduction en masse occurs when a hernial sac is pushed back into the preperitoneal space without freeing the entrapped contents, so the loop of bowel remains incarcerated or strangulated inside the sac.

 

Clinically, the external bulge disappears, giving a false impression of successful reduction, but the patient may still develop bowel obstruction or strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Characterized by a W-shaped loop of bowel, where the central loop inside the sac may become strangulated while the outer loops appear viable.

 

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Occurs when a retroperitoneal organ (colon, bladder, cecum) forms part of the hernial sac wall, common in elderly men.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: A hernia whose contents cannot be reduced, leading to obstruction. Unlike reduction en masse, the sac is not forcibly pushed back into the abdomen. If left untreated, it might lead to Strangulation.

choices.text: Deep femoral artery
Medial circumflex femoral
Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for right hip pain 30 minutes after she fell while walking around in her room. Examination shows groin tenderness. The range of motion of the hip is limited because of pain. An X-ray is shown below. Which of the following arteries was most likely damaged in the patient's fall?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Medial circumflex femoral

choices.text: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) and stenting

questions.text: A 45 year old patient underwent a lap cholecystectomy for gallstones. On day 2 in the postoperative period, he experienced fever and pain in the right hypochondrium. Ultrasonography reveals 200cc of fluid in the GB fossa. What is your next step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ultrasound-guided drainage

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin malignancy and often occurs on sun-exposed areas like the face, particularly near the nose and medial canthus. The classical presentation is a slow-growing ulcer with raised, pearly rolled edges (“rodent ulcer”). It is locally invasive but rarely metastasizes. Risk factors include chronic sun exposure, fair skin, and genetic conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum. Early recognition and excision prevent extensive local tissue destruction. 

 

The histopathology BCC shows acanthotic epidermis with underlying basaloid malignant cells in nodular pattern with peripheral palisading and retraction artifact:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo maligna melanoma: Occurs on sun-damaged skin in elderly patients, usually as a slowly enlarging pigmented macule on the face, not as an ulcerative lesion. Unlike BCC, it shows marked pigmentation and irregular borders.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a firm, indurated, ulcerated lesion with everted margins, often on lips, ears, or chronically inflamed/scarred areas. It has a higher metastatic potential compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A benign lesion, usually pigmented, flat or raised, and stable in size. Malignant change is rare but can evolve into melanoma. Nevi do not present as ulcerative lesions near the nose.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?
questions.solution: Ans. A) PCL

choices.text: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
Closed fracture of the distal phalanx
Rupture of the extensor digitorum tendon at its point of insertion
Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in his right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when his finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, his right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity.

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is breastfeeding her 2-month-old infant presents to the clinic with a painful, red, and swollen lump in her right breast. She reports having a fever and feeling unwell for the past 24 hours. On examination, there is a tender, fluctuant mass in the upper outer quadrant of breast. What will be the next best investigation to evaluate this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) USG

questions.text: A 76-year-old man who has had multiple episodes of pancreatitis presents to his physician’s office with mild epigastric pain and 9.1-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. The patient also describes daily foul-smelling stools that “float” in the toilet bowl. CT of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Pancreatic enzyme replacement

choices.text: MRM in node negative patients
MRM in node positive patients
BCT in node negative patients
BCT in node positive patients

questions.text: In which of the given cases is this procedure usually performed?
questions.solution: Ans. C) BCT in node negative patients

choices.text: Phantom limb pain
Foreign body reaction

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a below-knee amputation of the right lower leg. Three weeks ago, he had an acute arterial embolism that could not be revascularized in time to save the leg. He now reports episodic hot, shooting, and tingling pain in the right lower leg that began shortly after the amputation. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His current medications are metformin and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a slightly erythematous stump with clean sutures. The skin overlying the stump is warm and well-perfused. Muscle strength and sensation are normal throughout the remaining extremity and the left lower extremity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Phantom limb pain

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a mass in the right kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a follow-up examination. He has had a short stature since birth and underwent diagnostic testing. Genetic analyses showed a gain of function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. He has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 90th percentile for weight. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Frontal bossing

questions.text: The following CXR appearance is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulmonary edema

 

The chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral perihilar opacities, a "batwing" pattern, and increased interstitial markings, consistent with pulmonary edema. This appearance is typical in congestive heart failure or fluid overload, where fluid accumulates in the lungs’ interstitium and alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Usually does not show diffuse haziness; may show wedge-shaped infarcts or be normal.

 

Option C. Pneumoconiosis: Characterized by small nodular or reticulonodular opacities, predominantly in the upper zones.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Involves hilar lymphadenopathy and reticulonodular infiltration rather than diffuse edema.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Decompression

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 2 hours after the sudden onset of scrotal pain. Physical examination shows nontender testes and a tender, 5-mm, bluish nodule at the superior pole of the left testis. The patient undergoes urgent surgical exploration of the scrotum. During the operation, the nodule on the superior pole of the testis is found to be necrotic. In the process of embryologic development, this nodule forms as a result of the activity of which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) MIF

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of constipation has been experiencing intermittent left- sided abdominal pain and fevers for 2 days. He came to the emergency department immediately after he noticed blood in his toilet this morning. His heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 18/ min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination the physician notes copious amounts of bright red blood per rectum. The physician immediately places two large bore intravenous lines, administers fluid, and sends blood for type and screen. Which of the following is the most likely appearance of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A)
